data.text: The One Thing You Did Not Pack, but Really Wished You Did on Your Last Bike Touring Trip?
I am starting to stage my gear for a month long tour up the UK in June. And so my question for the group is: On your last trip, what was the one thing you didn‚Äôt pack, but really wished you did?
Toilet paper...
data.author: Jan Skulicz

data.text: got that box checked!
data.author: Scott Hyman

data.text: girlfriend! lol
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: - Don't do it. ü§£
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: A small folding chair like the Helinox or similar. We used to have sit pads, but lost them somewhere along the way and there were times sat around a fire in the cold dirt that things would have been a lot nicer with something to sit on.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: Hey where are you heading? I'm touring around the UK coast starting in May.
data.author: Nathan Rice-Smith

data.text: A pillowcase. Had to sleep on my dirty folded up jacket, not comfy at all ü§£
data.author: Jessica Kittle

data.text: A proper raincoat. I got surprised by some rain and those days have been really miserable. Whereas ive hiked with proper gear and been fine. I'm also planning on heading up to Scotland soon, and looking at getting a gore shakedry jacket.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I own that jacket. Well worth the cost. Very light weight and totally works as advertised.
data.author: Scott Hyman

data.text: know any good pants to go with?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Waterproof pants.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: where was this? Have you found some that work well?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: - in Estonia üá™üá™ last year. I have recently bought Endura GV500, but have not tested them yet in rainy weather.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: I have been doing it long enough to know what to take. My challenge is to decide what small item to leave behind. But things I do take that others may not. Earplugs. Birds wake up at 4 in the morning. 2 buffs. One for my neck and another to keep the ear plus in. An exped air superlight pillow. At least 2 navigation devices and the mounts to put them on the handlebar. If its a long tour, a paper map. Aeropex headphones. 2 mobile phones in case one dies. A spares wad of Cash hidden on the bike.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: how long a tour before you decide to bring two phones? Mine stopped charging three weeks into my current one. This might not be a bad idea.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I have almost always got 2 phones on my bike. Most of us have a spare. I also carry 2 Wahoo Bolts as I picked up a second one very cheaply.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: are both decent phones or is the second a cheap backup?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Both decent phones. My new one and my old one.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: I have an old pair of Performance pants my mother bought me for my first tour about 30 years ago. Still work great.
data.author: Scott Hyman

data.text: Very good. Why do you think I would be interested in your pants ? üòÅüòÅ
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: sorry, I responded to the wrong post
data.author: Scott Hyman

data.text: The proper gas for my msr pocket stove. The gas canister from Decathlon I bought in Spain made a sticky stinky mess on my stove.
data.author: Sarah Delafortrie

data.text: unless you fly then you have to get gas at your destination
data.author: Francois Swanepoel

data.text: The only camping shop I found in Spain was Decathlon. Oh my... what a stinky mess. I'll buy a new pocket stove.
data.author: Sarah Delafortrie

data.text: Some other ideas I thought of, A book for rest days. Panniers. I've found the saddle bag insufficient for long trips. Possibly a decent knife.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: A warmer layer - some spring mornings were very cold My portable headphones for evening entertainment
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: It depends what kind of tour it will be, camping or hotels?
data.author: Francois Swanepoel

data.text: A bike‚Ä¶ üòÇ
data.author: Nigel Clark

data.text: Suntan lotion
data.author: Scott Jones

data.text: Last weekend I slept in a tent at 3 degrees Celsius, wish I had brought a hat.
data.author: Birgit Deploige

data.text: Thanks everyone for the input!!üôè
data.author: Scott Hyman

data.text: Wok or good frying pan
data.author: David Frederick

data.text: a wok on a bike tour ?üòÇ
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: : We were on the road for three months. In the middle of the country vegetables are hard to find in restaurants. I craved a stir fry or sometimes a fried egg.
data.author: David Frederick

data.text: no doubt but I‚Äôm guessing it adds a lot of weight and awkward to pack ?
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: sure. That‚Äôs why we didn‚Äôt pack it. But we missed not having a way to cook. We only had a pot for boiling water.
data.author: David Frederick

data.text: Thick socks - my feet were freezing at night
data.author: Adrian Camm

data.text: A Tupperware to keep food for the evening so you can cook only once a day.
data.author: Jos√© Escarpa

data.text: Neoprene shoes to cycle in the rain with warm feet.
data.author: Giulia Juh√©

data.text: A firearm to deal with overly aggressive drivers. üòû
data.author: Wayne Wood

data.text: Avon skin-so-soft cream to ward off the midgies
data.author: Dave Rogers

data.text: Personal safety alarm with 120 db, very loud! I used it already twice and it kept away assholes who tried to steal my bike at one occasion and the other time when a guy tried to break in my van at night.
data.author: Carmen Schuster

data.text: Paper map. Research which map(s)to take. Road signs or lack of can be a nightmare. Locals not knowledgable if they don't bike.
data.author: Lorraine Elliott

data.text: A flamethrower for the Scottish midges, especially in June..
data.author: Lucy Hann
